And here's an email we have from Sean(ph) in Portland, Oregon.
My first two years after graduating from Wake Forrest, I worked for the university as an admissions counselor.
I recruited, interviewed and evaluated applications for admission.
Waitlist are an essential thing for smaller schools, especially ones that require/guarantee housing during freshman year.
Students that were waitlisted were required to send back a form stating their continued interest in possibly attending.
I was a champion for those students on the waitlist.
My hypothesis was that students who are accepted off the waitlist wound up doing as well if not better than the average student and more valuable for the university.
First, these students really wanted to be at Wake.
Second, there is something to prove factor.
And - well, that's an element, too.

And as I understand it, for meeting other things, Steven Yoder, as soon as people say you really need to express interest in going to school, about half of the people on the waitlist drop off at that point.

Isaac Yoder and his dad, Steven Yoder, write the - Steven is chief at the Wall Street Journal San Francisco bureau.
Together they write the Yoder & Son column at the Wall Street Journal.
And they joined us today from the studios of our member station in San Francisco, KQED.
I can't buy razor blades.
That wouldn't be a news story except I seem to share this predicament with quite a few men this weekend.
I bought Gillette's new five-blade razor, called the Fusion ProGlide.
I kind of had to.
Stores have already stopped stocking replacement blades for the old, merely Fusion razor.
You may find this a crass commercial tactic to force men to buy new razors.
The company prefers to think of it as keeping pace with modern shaving technology.
You can't expect them to keep making Fusion blades, any more than Sony should keep making eight-track tapes.
Drugstores I've tried in two cities have the new razor, but they've already run out of the new replacement blades.
They tell me to check every day, like people in old Soviet Moscow used to check in at bakeries, desperately hoping to show up on the one day of the month the store got fresh bread.
Now, I'm not one of those curmudgeons who grouse that their grandfather used a straight razor, stropped on a buffalo hide, so they use one too.
My grandfather used a double-edged razor that left so many cuts he had to report for duty as a police sergeant with half a dozen tiny blood-soaked toilet tissue balls affixed to his chin.
Chris?
Purer expression cannot be found of the principle of rule by judicial fiat.
In the face of Justice Stevens' experience, the experience of all others, in state legislature or Congress, is, it appears of little consequence.
Nina Totenberg, NPR News, Washington.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
The Bush administration is in the midst of a number of legal and procedural battles over the war on terrorism.
News analyst Daniel Schorr has been taking note of a shift.
For the past half dozen years since 9/11, the Bush administration has been able to prevail over his Democratic opponents by invoking the words patriot and terrorism.
But these broad interpretations of the Constitution and the law are no longer fairing so well.

For one, its effort to grant immunity to major telephone companies that may have broken the law by cooperating with the National Security Agency on eavesdropping, that's running into heavy opposition.
Democrats and some Republicans in Congress are dubious about the constitutionality of retroactive immunity.
For another thing, Retired Judge Michael Mukasey, who had first seemed a shoo- in for attorney general, has run into stormy weather in a Senate Judiciary Committee over the issue of torture.
As to say whether water boarding, simulated drowning can be defined as torture, Mukasey refused to answer.
The White House pleas that he doesn't know, because he doesn't have access to classified documents.
Say what?
A nominee for attorney general can't see secret documents?
The administration is not having much better luck in the courts.
In a criminal trial in Dallas, the federal prosecutor accused a Muslim charity of giving material support to terrorists.
Under a Bush executive order, much of the evidence was not produced in public.
In the end, the jury rendered a not guilty verdict for one defendant on all but one count.
On the other 196 counts, the jury could not agree and there was a mistrial.
The government had lost previous similar cases in Chicago and Tampa, Florida.

Until recently, the administration has been able to operate under a questionable legal theory that an anti-terrorist campaign defined as a war gives the president an exemption from normal adherence to law.
It might be called the Nixon doctrine.
It was Nixon who once said that when the president does it that means it's not illegal.
Nixon learned differently and so may President Bush.
This is Daniel Schorr.
This week in The Hague, the war crimes trial of Slobodan Milosevic is set to resume after yet another delay due to his ill health.
The former Yugoslav president is trying to get his trial postponed until next year because of ongoing medical problems.
He's defending himself on charges of genocide and crimes against humanity during the Balkan wars of the 1990s.
This high-profile trial was seen as an essential step toward confronting the crimes of the past and building democracy in the former Yugoslavia.
To see if that's happening, we turn now to Misha Glenny, who has written extensively on the Balkans.
